user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue:
```c
void UT_Stub_CopyToReturnValue(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const void *BufferPtr, size_t BufferSize)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
    if (StubPtr != NULL)
    {
        /* If the size does not match, there is a bug */
        if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != BufferSize)
        {
            UtAssert_Abort("Size mismatch in setting return value");
        }
        else
        {
            memcpy(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, BufferPtr, BufferSize);
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position = BufferSize;
        }
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in the provided code fragment. Evidence:
- FuncKey is only used as an argument to UT_GetStubEntry and is never assigned to or altered in the function body.
- BufferPtr is declared as const void * and is only read (passed to memcpy); the pointer itself is not assigned or changed.
- BufferSize is only read (compared and used as an argument to memcpy and assigned to a struct field) and is not assigned to or altered.
- The only write operations are to memory referred to by StubPtr (memcpy to StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr and StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position = BufferSize), which is permitted: the object pointed to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but no pointer parameter variable is modified here.

Therefore, there are no fragments in this function that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
